text: Amazon Prime is the independent corner video store of streaming. Without the judgmental clerk.
author: Lileks

text:
Netflix: hey here’s a new series about attractive serious people with powers who are back from the dead in the future; it makes no sense

Amazon Prime: so, "Mondo Cane?" To Tell the Truth eps? 1974 sex musical? Maisel? Bond? 40s noir? Cartoons?
author: Lileks

text: It was for research purposes. I have a long-standing aversion to the Stooges. Growing up, I thought Moe was a grim sadist, and he repelled me.
author: Lileks

text: The entire time I was having a voice-msg WhatsApp convo with daughter in Brazil about the dangers of nihilism in comedy she had no idea I was watching a Three Stooges short where Moe shaved off slices of Larry’s scalp with a hand sander. On the planet Venus
author: Lileks

text: Lucky for us we were spared a Murray Slaughter sitcom, because he was a bitter little man of limited talent whose dominant internal script was how unlikely it was he could attract a woman like Mar.
author: Lileks

text: So imagine a show that gave him some pathos and depth, as well as explored his demons and his inconsistent decency. I think Ted Knight could have carried it off, too. (3/3)
author: Lileks

text: Ted, in the end, was the only character on the show who had his life together: he was happily married, unlike Grant; he adopted a kid; he kept his job when everyone else was axed. And he was the only character capable of uncomplicated happiness. (2/x)
author: Lileks

text: If I’d been an MTM productions exec after the end of the “Mary Tyler Moore Show,” I would have proposed a show about Ted Baxter, done “Lou Grant” style. Drop the sitcom tropes. (1/x)
author: Lileks

text: Twitter needs an bedit utton.
author: Lileks

text: You’re right; my error
author: Lileks

text: Alan Reed had a long career before Flintstone, but nothing like the guy who voiced George Jetson: he was in a *1933* Busby Berkeley musical.
author: Lileks

text: The Canadian radio announcer just said the the guy who voiced Fred Flintstone based “dabba dabba do” on his mother’s catch phrase, “A little dab’ll do ya” and now I weep for the state of cultural literacy
author: Lileks

text: Daughter prank to me today by sending a picture of a homemade tattoo and saying she’d just gotten it. All you need to know about parenthood is that your kids can give you tachycardia from a distance of 5600 miles away
author: Lileks

text: Almost made a simple, harmless tweet about a new salsa I like, and realized I would drowned by people telling me I should really try another brand which is better and also only available in the town of Butlap, TX (pop 58)
author: Lileks

text: The England of the Sixties vibe is nicely done. You can accomplish a lot with lamps and mantle bric-a-brac.
author: Lileks

text: I’m watching the Inspector Morse prequels, having never watched any of the 37 seasons of “Inspector Morse.” I’m sure I’m missing everything, but gather he likes singing and is good at deduction and his colleagues aren’t as smart
author: Lileks

text: Bill Stern was an original, but the stories told on the air makes me think “BS” was coined to describe his yarns.
author: Lileks

text: There’s only one Poirot for me, and that’s Jon Polito. Shame he never played the role
author: Lileks

text: Amazon recommended “An Inspector Calls” because I had watched “The ABC Murders,” which I gather infuriated Poirot fans b/c it gave the character depth and pathos
author: Lileks

text: Surprised the BBC's “An Inspector Calls” is a one-off, not a beloved six-season series about  a low-key detective who informs a family of Victorian rotters that they share collective blame for a murder in every episode
author: Lileks

text: It’s beginning to look a lot like Christmas
author: Lileks

text: Ah, good, it’s raining, so we’ll have a thick sheaf of ice that keeps the snow below from melting for three weeks.
author: Lileks

text: In the first she reaches out to grab the sleeve of Robert Young, who is wearing an immaculate and nicely accessorized cowboy outfit, and he *snarls* “don’t touch me.” Because he is a he-man.
author: Lileks

text: There are TEN movies in the series, and I presume she seduces a he-man woman-hater in each, then leaves him. They are comedies.
author: Lileks

text: Watching a movie where Ann Sothern convinces a he-man woman-hater to change his ways. He lives alone in the Congo on a rubber plantation.
author: Lileks

text: It is not the biopic of the real Christopher Robin, who apparently was unhappy. I’ve no desire to see that. It’s like knowing Dennis the Menace was estranged from the father who had to keep drawing him as a child for decades.
author: Lileks

text: Watching “Christopher Robin,”  a nice mix of mild family-friendly humor and stab-you-in-the-heart unslakable aching sadness. Nice trick
author: Lileks

text: Spent 20 minutes furiously texting with daughter on the other side of the world about a cartoon math problem. Highlight of the week ;)
author: Lileks

text: “American in Paris” come on the radio and I was reminded that the opening sequence quotes the pig toy music box that survived the sinking of the Titanic.
author: Lileks

text: Shark, not stark
author: Lileks

text: But was a stark really jumped? What if witnesses were wrong, and it was a dolphin - and no one jumped at all? We went to investigate, and found surprising resistance to two reporters with Boston accents
author: Lileks

text: When a true crime podcast narrator says “yep, it’s the small-town music” to introduce the segment about a sleepy southern town where an injustice was done, you suspect the genre may have jumped the shark.
author: Lileks

text: “He’s been so snuggly tonight,” my wife said. “It’s because he’s going to barf gouts,” I said." He’s had breath like a frat house in pledge week all night."
author: Lileks

text: Birch the dog gently requested to go outside, where it is 3 above, so that he could bring up the meatballs he purloined. I obliged.
author: Lileks

text: Of all the things I forgot about “The Sopranos,” the Lauren Bacall cameo tops the list
author: Lileks

text: Served David Byrne at a college bar; he wanted coffee and two aspirin, and asked if the tv volume could be increased so he could hear the documentary on African drumming
author: Lileks

text: Not yet! Iowa City is the next Iowa town I do, I think. (I’m usually 10 months out on these. I have a big backlog)
author: Lileks

text: Found in the office: rare promotional material from the 1978 ABC show “Staplin’ Jones,” about a widowed pioneer who ran the town’s only stapling shop, and solved crime. Ran one season; came back as summer replacement in variety form.
author: Lileks

text:
Blizzard wind ripped the storm door out of the frame, sheared the screws right out of the plate that held the pneumatic door-closer bolted to the frame.

“Storm door.” YOU HAD ONE JOB
author: Lileks

text: Saw “Stan & Ollie.” Rather predictable arc, but the performances are astonishing and the film has a quiet sense of decency that feels rare. Also, *funny.*
author: Lileks

text: Went down slippery steps with the dog in a leash; neighbor had left gate open while he shoveled, and the dogs got out. Birch lunged. Took tremendous fall. But the AirPods did not fall out! Man, you could wear these things while boxing.
author: Lileks

text: Greensleeves, like that Peanuts skating song, eventually serves to make grownups feel bittersweet about Christmas
author: Lileks

text: Eight inches of snow, and the harpist in the atrium is playing “Greensleeves.” It’s like someone bumped the record player and its jumped back three cuts.
author: Lileks

text: Surely I’m not the only one bothered by the fact that the motion in the Sopranos opening credits is all in the same direction, except for the Pizzaland store
author: Lileks

text: I mean, the four-roll option at least suggests “you got other things to do"
author: Lileks

text: The only “bathroom tissue” options left at the store tonight were 24-roll bales, which exist only to make you confront the inescapable reality of existence
author: Lileks

text: Just saw someone on the street who made me want to say “you look like a young Guindon Minnesotan” but no one under 50 would get the reference. Sic transit, etc https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dick_Guindon …
author: Lileks

text: Best fake I’ve seen in years.
author: Lileks

text: Note from the Post Office that I have a parcel waiting; probably the box I sent to Brazil two months ago. I tracked it; it spent 1 day in Brazil, and then went to South Korea. Guess the Post Office in Brazil said “eh, delivering it, that’s work.” Gah.
author: Lileks

text: Rewatching the Sopranos and enjoying it.  I still think Boardwalk Empire is richer, has better secondary characters, and zero scenes that could be set to a laugh track. All it lacks is Gandolfini, but that’s everything.
author: Lileks

text: When I walk inside, my eyes streaming from the cold wind, I just consider it practice for getting some really bad news
author: Lileks

text: It took a long, long time, but I finally found a whiskey I wanted to pour down the drain. All the reviews rave about its "subtle notes of paper and mild leather" and whatnot, but to me it’s like licking a half-eaten rawhide the dog buried in a hogsty
author: Lileks

text:
Me, 1st time I MC’d at Orchestra Hall: HOW DO MY EYEBROWS LOOK ARE MY SHOELACE TIPS SHINED 

Today, after 22 seasons: eh, my fly’s probably zipped
author: Lileks

text: Sitting by the radiator trying to un-numb my feet so I can go back outside and re-numb them
author: Lileks
